L23365:
The National Labour Inspectorate’s inspections cover:

  • all employers, and in the area of occupational safety and health, as well as legality of employment – also entrepreneurs and other organisational units not being employers, as long as work for their benefit is performed by natural persons, also those conducting economic activity on their own account, irrespective of the basis of performing work;
  • entities operating as employment agencies, offering HR advice, vocational consultancy and temporary employment;
  • Voluntary Labour Corps, social integration centres and clubs, specialised military bodies mentioned in the provisions on military service of professional soldiers, as well as foreign entrepreneurs who may benefits from the freedom to provide services, having the right to, and lawfully conducting activity related to employment agency services, personnel consultancy, vocational advice or temporary work in the territory of Member States of the European Union, European Economic Area states not belonging to the European Union and states not being parties to the agreement on the European Economic Area;
  • employers posting workers to the territory of Poland in the scope as laid down in the Act of 10 June 2016 on posting of workers in the framework of the provision of services;
  • entrepreneurs or other organisational units for whose benefit, in the framework of their economic activity, a mandated task is performed or services are provided by a contractor or a service-provider – with regard to payment to such persons of the  remuneration resulting from the minimum hourly rate, in accordance with provisions of the Act of 10 October 2002 on the minimum remuneration for work.

The above-mentioned entities are covered by inspections irrespective of the sector in whichthey operate, their size and ownership.
L23366:
In accordance with article 23 par. 1 of the Act on the National Labour Inspectorate, during an inspection, a labour inspector has the right to:

  1. have free access to the premises, buildings and rooms of the inspected entity;
  2. conduct inspections of buildings, rooms, workstations, machinery and equipment as well as technological and working processes;
  3. demand from the entity under inspection, and from all of its employees and persons who are or used to be employed there or who perform or used to perform work for the benefit of the inspected entity on grounds other than an employment relationship, including persons performing economic activity on their own account, as well as persons taking advantage of employment agency services, written and oral explanations in relation to matters covered by the inspection as well as to summon and interrogate such persons in connection with the inspection;
  4. demand presentation of documents related to construction, reconstruction or modernisation and start-up of an employment establishment, technical plans and 44 drawings, technical and technological documentation, results of expert analyses, examinations and measurements concerning production or other activity of the inspected entity, as well as to be provided with samples of raw materials and components used, manufactured or generated during production processes, in the amount necessary to make analyses or examinations if they are related to the on-going inspection;
  5. demand presentation of personal files and any other documents connected with work performed by employees and other persons performing work on grounds other than an employment relationship;
  6. demand from the employer posting an employee to the territory of the Republic of Poland or a person acting on the employer’s behalf to provide information, documents or statements related to posting of workers to the territory of the Republic of Poland or from the territory of the Republic of Poland, in the scope of inspection provided for in the Act of 10 June 2016 on the posting of workers in the framework of the provision of services;
  7. become acquainted with decisions issued by other authorities competent for supervision and inspection of working conditions and their implementation;
  8. record processes and results of inspections described in point 2 above with sound or image recording equipment;
  9. make copies or extracts of documents indispensable for an inspection, as well as comparisons and calculations based on documents, or if necessary demand them from the inspected entity;
  10. check the identity of persons executing work or staying on premises of the inspected entity, as well as persons taking advantage of employment agency services, interrogate them and demand statements with regard to legality of employment or performance of any other paid activity;
  11. resort to the assistance of surveyors and experts as well as accredited laboratories.
L23367: The NLI’s action programme is developed with regard to recommendations of the Labour Protection Council and parliamentary commissions. The SLIC work plan and the plans of international organizations play a key role in shaping future tasks of the Inspectorate. The programme is also based on the results from conducted inspections and on the current picture of the labour market. At the stage of drafting an action programme the NLI consults institutional partners and social partners about its content – the elaborated document includes suggestions and thematic proposals of, inter alia, trade union organizations. Thus, annual action programmes of the NLI thus reflect current problems in the field of labour protection, which we intend to respond to by implementing a long-term action plan, aimed at strategic goals in 2016-2018, as well as the annual programme.

L23369:
In the scope of ACT (Portuguese labour inspectorate) are included:

  • Inquiry of labour accidents
  • Inquiry of professional diseases
  • Construction
  • Footwear industry
  • Fisheries
  • Asbestos
  • Biological agents
  • Chemicals
  • Carcinogenic
  • ATEX (explosive atmospheres)
  • GMOs (genetically modified organisms)

Since 2014 the inspection competence of ACT related to OSH has been limited for employers in private sector. The competence for inspection of OSH for employers in the public sector, since 2014, was assigned to several public auditing entities: the Sectoral General Inspection services of each ministry and, cumulatively, the Financial General Inspection. Now, since May 2017, ACT has regained this competence, but is waiting for its regulation to be able to exercise it.
L23371:
The Strategic Plan of ACT for 2017-2020 has three main goals:

  • To promote the reduction of occupational accidents and diseases
  • To promote the reduction of undeclared work and related phenomena

To promote the development and organizational well-being in ACT.

In order to follow these main goals, two methodologies are adopted: inspection activity and national tripartite campaigns, carried out with social and institutional partners. These campaigns comprises, mainly:

  • Training (with social partners);
  • Information (with social partners);
  • Inspection (by ACT and other inspection bodies, when appropriate, such as social security, taxes, foreign services, national maritime authority and police).

In line with the principles to be followed in drawing up plan and report activities of Portuguese services and public administration bodies, ACT also had an Activity Plan for 2016 which is part of the strategic goals, programs and guidelines identified in the ACT Strategy 2017-2020, reflecting ACT’s vision to face the challenges in a frame of financial constraints resulting from the current economic and social context, without losing sight of the need for continuing the efforts to modernize and simply the procedures, reducing bureaucracy and rationalizing the resource use.
L23373: The scope of OHSA-MT is to ensure that the physical, psychological and social well being of all workers in all workplaces are promoted, and to ensure that they are safeguarded by whoever is so obliged to do.
L23374: Powers of inspectors are established by the Occupational Health and Safety Authority Act. These powers reflect the principles of ILO Labour Inspection Convention C081.
L23375: OHSA-MT develops a rolling plan of work which is updated and amended annually. This plan of work outlines the main tasks to be carried out by the OHSA. The implementation of these tasks is measured against pre-set KPIs which are updated regularly. The tripartite Board of OHSA-MT is given the opportunity to provide input and suggest new initiatives.

L23494:
The indicator ‘Economic and sector profile’ provides basic background data on the economic structures of the countries. The GDP per capita is a major indicator of the economic overall wealth of a society, which also influences the status of OSH. 
The GDP per capita is displayed in Euro or as so-called Purchasing Power Standard PPS. In the first case the 
Eurostat explains these two categories as follows: 
“Current price figures are typically expressed in (millions of) national currency and euro. They can be directly observed but include inflation effects.” 
“PPS are fictive 'currency' units that remove differences in purchasing power, i.e. different price levels between countries.”
By using PPS the statistical offices take into account that goods and services are in general cheaper in countries with lower GDP per capita, and higher in countries with higher GDP per capita.
